Award.AwardTitle: Ordered Algebraic Structures and Related Topics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the travel of US participants, in particular students and early career researchers, to the conference "Ordered Algebraic Structures and Related Topics" held at the Centre International de Rencontres Mathematiques (CIRM) in Luminy, France on October 12-16, 2015. The conference covers a broad range of topics in ordered algebraic structures, a dynamic area of mathematics in which there have been a number of important recent developments. The activity will contribute to the training of graduate students and junior researchers and promote the exchange of ideas among the world's leading experts in ordered algebraic structures. Eight internationally recognized experts have been chosen to give survey talks to promote interaction, facilitate participation and introduce junior researchers to the subject. It is of substantial intellectual advantage for US-based researchers to have the opportunity to participate in this workshop and to bring back to their campuses and communities the benefits of these interactions.

The conference will bring together major researchers in five general areas of interest: Ordered Groups, Real Algebra and Valuations, Model Theory of Ordered Structures and Algorithms in Semi-algebraic Geometry, Quadratic Forms and Abstract Spaces of Orderings, Real Algebraic and Analytic Geometry and O-minimality, Positive Polynomials and Optimization. In addition to the survey talks there will be ample opportunities for young researchers to present and discuss their work in both formal and informal settings. Additional information is available at the conference web site, http://scientific-events.weebly.com/1155.html

POR.DRECONTENT:
n the Fall 1984, Paris mathematicians Francoise Delon, Max Dickmann, and Danielle Gondard began a  seminar on Ordered Algebraic Structures. This seminar has continued to the present time, and is known informally as DDG.  The seminar has involved over 400 speakers  from 25 countries, with 60 percent of its speakers coming  from outside France. Seminal developments in ordered structures were reported in the seminar; sample topics include the model theory of real exponentiation, C-minimality, applications in real algebraic geometry and in valued fields, theory of higher level orderings, model theory of the p-adics, abstract real spectra, and the Pierce-Birkhoff conjecture.

The Luminy conference celebrated DDG's success over thirty years by assembling major researchers in five general areas of interest: Ordered Groups, Real Algebra and Valuations, Model Theory of Ordered Structures and Algorithms in Semi-algebraic Geometry, Quadratic Forms and Abstract Spaces of Orderings, Real Algebraic and Analytic Geometry, O-minimality, and Positive Polynomials and Optimization. Seven internationally recognized experts gave survey talks at the conference which promoted interaction between the areas, facilitated participation and introduced junior researchers to the area.

The funding was used to support the travel of 11 US-based participants to Luminy, France. The group included two graduate students, two recent PhDs and two female participants. Five of the sponsored participants gave talks and two presenetd posters in front of an audience of renowned international experts. The workshop fostered research interactions between different areas and provided an informal setting for graduate students and younger researchers to learn of the newest trends and interact with some of the most prominent researchers around the world. The workshop included a poster session as well as a Young Researchers evening session to give junior participants ample opportunity to present ther work in front of expert audience. The workshop featured an international session on Women in Mathematics with a discussion on gender gap in mathematics and related issues. Given the breadth and importance of the meeting the ooportunities afforded by traveling to the conference were significant.
